qas.question: When are infectious diseases called contagious diseases?

answers.text: when they are easily transmitted by contact with an ill person

qas.question: What is a contagious disease a subset of?
What sets a contagious disease after from a standard infectious disease?
Diseases with vector transmission or sexual transmission don't often require what type of isolation?
What is not always respected in popular use?

plausible_answers.text: when they are easily transmitted by contact with an ill person

qas.question: When are infectious diseases called impossible diseases?
What is a contagious disease more important than?
What sets a contagious disease equal to a standard infectious disease?

plausible_answers.text: specialized connotation of the word "contagious" and "contagious disease"

qas.question: What is always respected in popular use?

context: Infectious diseases are sometimes called contagious disease <a0_0><b5_0>when they are easily transmitted by contact with an ill person<b5_0/><a0_0/> or their secretions (e.g., influenza). Thus, a contagious disease is a subset of <a1_0><b6_0>infectious disease<b6_0/><a1_0/> that is <a2_0><b7_0>especially infective or easily transmitted<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Other types of infectious/transmissible/communicable diseases with more specialized routes of infection, such as vector transmission or sexual transmission, are usually not regarded as "contagious", and often do not require <a3_0>medical<a3_0/> isolation (sometimes loosely called quarantine) of victims. However, this <a4_0><b8_0>specialized connotation of the word "contagious"<a4_0/> and "contagious disease"<b8_0/> (easy transmissibility) is not always respected in popular use.
